case_name: Appellant v. Respondent (Civil Appeal No. 2186 of 1968)

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2186 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2186 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 3, 1967 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 250 of 1964 Revision No. 172.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 3, 1967 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 250 of 1964  Revision No. 172 .

facts.text: The assessee is a dealer in Hides and Skins at Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a dealer in Hides and Skins at Madras. We are companycerned herein with its assessment for the year 1958-59.

facts.text: Assessment for the year 1958-59 was made on March 24, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned herein with its assessment for the year 1958-59. That assessment was made on March 24, 1961.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner enhanced the assessment on August 16, 1962 while disposing of the appeal by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated August 16, 1962, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner enhanced the assessment of the assessee while disposing of the appeal by the assessee.

facts.text: The assessing officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed two exemptions asked for by the assessee on the ground of interpolation in the relative documents.

anchor.surface_text: The assessing officer as well as the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes disallowed the two exemp- tions asked for by the assessee on the ground that there was interpolation in the, relative documents companyering the turnover.

facts.text: The Tribunal reversed the finding of interpolation and allowed the exemptions.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal reversed that finding of those authorities and allowed the exemptions asked for. It appears from the order of the Tribunal that it proceeded on the basis that there was numberInterpolation.

facts.text: The assessee filed appeal under S. 31 of the 1959 Act to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed its appeal under S. 31 of that Act and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner dealt with that appeal under that provision.

facts.text: The Tribunal followed the decision in Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Madras Division v. Sri Swami and Company.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal following the decision of the Madras High Court in Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Madras Division v. Sri Swami and Company, 1  accepted the companytention of the assessee.

facts.text: State of Madras went up in revision to the High Court under s. 38 of the 1959 Act.

anchor.surface_text: As against that decision, the State of Madras went up in revision to the High Court under s. 38 of the 1959 Act.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the revision petition.

anchor.surface_text: That petition was dismissed. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: The Madras Sales Tax Act, 1939 was repealed by the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959 which came into force on April 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The 1939 Act was repealed by the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959  to be hereinafter referred to as the 1959 Act . That Act came into force on April 1, 1959.

facts.text: Assessee was assessed after the 1959 Act came into force.

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier the assessee was assessed after that Act came into force.

facts.text: Before enhancing the assessment the Appellate Assistant Commissioner gave opportunity to the assessee to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: Before enhancing the assessment the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had given opportunity to the assessee to show cause against the proposed enhancement.

facts.text: The turnover of the assessee during 1958-59 became charged with liability under the 1939 Act on March 31, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The turnover of the assessee during the year 1958-59 became charged with liability to pay sales-tax under the 1939 Act as and when the assessee effected sales and the total sales- tax liability of the assessee for that year became fixed Under the same Act on March 31, 1959.

facts.text: In Swami Co. case, assessee assessed on December 15, 1956 for 1955-56 under 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: In Swami Co.s case  supra  the assessee was assessed by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer for its turnover for the year 1955-56 under the 1939 Act. The order or assessment was passed on December 15, 1956.

facts.text: In Swami Co., assessee appealed to Commercial Tax Officer on February 15, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed an appeal before the Commercial Tax Officer on February 15, 1957.

facts.text: Appeal in Swami Co. transferred to Appellate Assistant Commissioner after 1959 Act.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal, the 1959 Act came into force on April 1, 1959. Thereafter the appeal was transferred to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Governor of Madras authorised Assistant Commercial Tax Officers by order dated September 15, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated September 15, 1939, in exercise of the powers companyferred on him by cl.  a  of s. 2 and sub-ss. 1 and 2 of S. 14 of the 1939 Act, the Governor of Madras authorised the Assistant Commercial Tax Officers

facts.text: The High Court opined that under 1939 Act appellate authority could not enhance assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has opined that under the 1939 Act, the appellate authority while exercising its appellate powers companyld number have enhanced the assessment of the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court finding of no merit in High Court's holding on exemptions.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbermerit in the second companytention. Therefore it will ,be companyvenient to dispose it of even before going to the facts of the case.

facts.text: Tribunal's finding of no interpolation is a finding of fact not interfered with by Supreme Court or High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This finding of the Tribunal is essentially a finding of fact and hence we Will number be justified in interfering with that finding and more so as the High Court has declined to interfere with that finding.

facts.text: Appeal to Tribunal by assessee aggrieved by AAC order.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by that order, the assessee took up the matter in appeal to Tribunal.

facts.text: High Court held additional exemptions justified by evidence.

anchor.surface_text: whether the High Court was justified in holding that the additional exemptions granted by the Tribunal were justified by the evidence on record.

facts.text: AAC rejected assessee's contention that he had no power to enhance.

There is no merit in the second contention.

issues.text: whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had power to enhance the assessment of the assessee

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the real controversy in the appeal namely whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had power to enhance the assessment of the assessee. The assessee is a dealer in Hides and Skins at Madras. We are concerned herein with its assessment for the year 1958-59.

issues.text: whether the immunity or protection from enhancement afforded to the assessee under the 1939 Act was a vested right preserved under the 1959 Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has opined that under the 1939 Act, the appellate authority while exercising its appellate powers could not have enhanced the assessment of the assessee. That was an immunity or protection afforded to the assessee under the 1939 Act. Such an immunity or protection was a vested right of the assessee.

issues.text: whether there is any basis for saying that the provisions of the 1959 Act relating to the determination of the assessment are more onerous than those in the 1939 Act

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no basis for saying that the provisions of the 1959 Act relating to the determination of the assessment are more onerous than those in the 1939 Act. The 1959 Act in our opinion merely simplified the procedure without touching the substance of the right of the parties.

issues.text: whether any assessee has any vested right in the procedure prescribed under the 1939 Act such that the new procedure under the 1959 Act cannot apply

anchor.surface_text: No assessee has any vested right in the procedure prescribed under the 1939 Act. So long as the new procedure laid down in the 1959 Act does not interfere with any of his vested rights,

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that the new procedure prescribed by law governs all pending cases.

holdings.text: The finding of the Tribunal that there was no interpolation in the documents is a finding of fact which should not be interfered with by this Court.

anchor.surface_text: This finding of the Tribunal is essentially a finding of fact and hence we Will number be justified in interfering with that finding and more so as the High Court has declined to interfere with that finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's reversal of lower authorities' finding on interpolation is factual; High Court declined interference; Supreme Court defers to such findings.

holdings.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner had power under Section 31 of the 1959 Act to enhance the assessment even for turnover charged under the 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the real companytroversy in the appeal namely whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had power to enhance the assessment of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.31 empowers AAC to confirm, reduce, enhance or annul; appeal filed under 1959 Act; combines old appellate and revisional powers without affecting substance.

holdings.text: There is no basis for saying that the provisions of the 1959 Act relating to determination of assessment are more onerous than those in the 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no basis for saying that the provisions of the 1959 Act relating to the determination of the assessment are more onerous than those in the 1939 Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1959 Act simplifies machinery by conferring enhancement power on first appellate authority; time limits favor assessee; no substantive change.

holdings.text: The 1959 Act merely simplified the procedure without touching the substance of the right of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: The 1959 Act in our opinion merely simplified the procedure without touching the substance of the right of the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Changes combine appellate and special revisional powers previously separate; purpose identical - prevent escapement/under-assessment.

holdings.text: No assessee has any vested right in the procedure prescribed under the 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: No assessee has any vested right in the procedure prescribed under the 1939 Act. So long as the new procedure laid down in the 1959 Act does number interfere with any of his vested rights,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural changes apply unless substantive rights affected; immunity from enhancement is procedural, not substantive.

holdings.text: The new procedure prescribed by law governs all pending cases.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that the new procedure prescribed by law governs all pending cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee appealed under S.31 of 1959 Act; pending proceedings transferred and governed by new law.

holdings.text: Section 61 of the 1959 Act does not preserve any immunity from enhancement as a vested right under the 1939 Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Savings clause preserves substantive rights, privileges, liabilities; procedural changes not protected; no right infringed.

holdings.text: The power conferred on the appellate authority under the 1959 Act is not wider than that the Commercial Tax Officer had under the 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The power companyferred on the appellate authority under the 1959 Act is number wider than that the Commercial Tax Officer had under the 1939 Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: CTO had appellate under S.11 and revisional under S.12(1); S.31 combines them.

holdings.text: Balasundaram's case was wrongly decided and some observations in Swami Co.'s case are not correct.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that Balasundarams case supra was wrongly decided and some of the observations in Swami Cos case supra are number companyrect though the decision in that case is number open to question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior decisions erred in treating procedural immunity as vested right; no infringement of substantive rights.

holdings.text: Before enhancing the assessment the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had given opportunity to the assessee to show cause against the proposed enhancement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Opportunity provided, satisfying natural justice in exercise of enhancement power.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no basis for saying that the provisions of the 1959 Act relating to the determination of the assessment are more onerous than those in the 1939 Act. The 1959 Act in our opinion merely simplified the procedure without touching the substance of the right of the parties. No benefit that was available to an assessee as regards the procedure, was taken away by the 1959 Act, if we ignore the remote possibility of an appeal pending before an Appellate Assistant Commissioner for more than three years and that authority failing to exercise his power to enhance the tax within that period.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Appellate Assistant Commissioner competent to enhance assessment; no vested right of assessee infringed by 1959 Act; High Court erred

In our opinion there is no basis for saying that the provisions of the 1959 Act relating to the determination of the assessment are more onerous than those in the 1939 Act. The 1959 Act in our opinion merely simplified the procedure without touching the substance of the right of the parties. No benefit that was available to an assessee as regards the procedure, was taken away by the 1959 Act, if we ignore the remote possibility of an appeal pending before an Appellate Assistant Commissioner for more than three years and that authority failing to exercise his power to enhance the tax within that period.
